channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: 5 ways the pandemic changed us for good, for bad and forever
item.description: This month marks five years since the pandemic began, and here are 5 things that changed permanently.
item.content:encoded:
This month marks five years since the pandemic began, and here are 5 things that changed permanently.

(Image credit: Dr. Kurt Papenfus)
item.dc:creator: John Daley

item.title: Musk, DOGE violated Constitution, judge says. And, when egg prices might drop
item.description: A federal judge ruled that Elon Musk and DOGE likely violated the Constitution when shuttering the USAID. And, a look at when egg prices are likely to drop.
item.content:encoded:
A federal judge ruled that Elon Musk and DOGE likely violated the Constitution when shuttering the USAID. And, a look at when egg prices are likely to drop.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Switching from gas to electric? Here are 3 appliances that are easy to install
item.description: Changing from gas to climate-friendly electric appliances often involves expensive retrofits. A growing list of companies offer stoves, heat pumps and water heaters that make it easier and cheaper.
item.content:encoded:
Changing from gas to climate-friendly electric appliances often involves expensive retrofits. A growing list of companies offer stoves, heat pumps and water heaters that make it easier and cheaper.

(Image credit: Jeff Brady)
item.dc:creator: Jeff Brady

item.title: How astronauts adjust when back on Earth after being in space
item.description: Astronauts face several risks during spaceflight, including exposure to radiation.
item.content:encoded:
Astronauts face several risks during spaceflight, including exposure to radiation.

(Image credit: Keegan Barber)
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: After historic indictment, doctors will keep mailing abortion pills over state lines
item.description: Doctors who mail abortion medication pills across state lines have been on alert ever since Louisiana, which bans abortion, indicted a New York doctor for mailing the pills to a woman there.
item.content:encoded:
Doctors who mail abortion medication pills across state lines have been on alert ever since Louisiana, which bans abortion, indicted a New York doctor for mailing the pills to a woman there.

(Image credit: Elissa Nadworny)
item.dc:creator: Rosemary Westwood

item.title: Family of U.S. student missing in the Dominican Republic believes she drowned
item.description: Sudiksha Konanki remains missing after she disappeared during a spring break trip with friends.
item.content:encoded:
Sudiksha Konanki remains missing after she disappeared during a spring break trip with friends.

(Image credit: Francesco Spotorno)
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: Stargazing, poetry and meditation: What connects NPR readers to their spirituality
item.description: NPR readers of different belief systems share the poignant rituals that make them feel close to their spirituality. For some, it's poetry and gardening, for others, it's meditation and community.
item.content:encoded: NPR readers of different belief systems share the poignant rituals that make them feel close to their spirituality. For some, it's poetry and gardening, for others, it's meditation and community.
item.dc:creator: Malaka Gharib

item.title: Trump's handling of Ukraine and tariffs has NATO rethinking the U.S.-made F-35 fighter
item.description: The F-35 was meant as a one-size-fits-all fighter that could be used across NATO. But strained U.S.-Europe relations are giving some member countries second thoughts about the U.S.-built plane.
item.content:encoded:
The F-35 was meant as a one-size-fits-all fighter that could be used across NATO. But strained U.S.-Europe relations are giving some member countries second thoughts about the U.S.-built plane.

(Image credit: Thomas Lohnes)
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Why did Israel resume the war in Gaza?
item.description: Israel launched deadly strikes in Gaza to pressure Hamas to agree to a new ceasefire. Hamas isn't budging, and more than half of recently freed hostages oppose the renewed war. Why is Israel doing it?
item.content:encoded:
Israel launched deadly strikes in Gaza to pressure Hamas to agree to a new ceasefire. Hamas isn't budging, and more than half of recently freed hostages oppose the renewed war. Why is Israel doing it?

(Image credit: Bashar Taleb)
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: Professional players' group likens tennis organizers to a 'cartel' in its lawsuit
item.description: The antitrust lawsuit filed by the Professional Tennis Players' Association says the organizations that run the sport hold "complete control over the players' pay and working conditions."
item.content:encoded:
The antitrust lawsuit filed by the Professional Tennis Players' Association says the organizations that run the sport hold "complete control over the players' pay and working conditions."

(Image credit: Kelly Barnes)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
